awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Mechanisms of UV inactivation of viruses for tailored disinfection applications
awd_abstract_narration:
1512616
Rodriguez

The goal of this proposal is to gain fundamental insights into the action of ultraviolet light on viruses. The study will examine the molecular level viral responses to ultraviolet irradiation to improve current ultraviolet light disinfection and design of future ultraviolet light technologies. The research aims to answer a number of fundamental questions around virus inactivation with ultraviolet light that can inform engineering practice, public health, and subsequent regulatory policy and thus has broad reaching impacts.

The proposed activity will advance knowledge in a number of key areas. New fundamental knowledge will be developed into the molecular-level response of viruses to ultraviolet light irradiation during disinfection practice. Specifically, in addition to adenoviruses, new studies will be performed on another double stranded DNA virus - JC polyomavirus - to test the generalizability of the findings with adenoviruses in response to low-pressure and medium-pressure ultraviolet light. This research will move beyond the traditional evaluations of laboratory strains of adenoviruses and isolate and test environmental strains to determine if there are any differences in the ultraviolet light -response that may be related to acclimated responses (such as DNA repair) from repeated exposure to and propagation in laboratory cell culture lines. A number of new areas in molecular microbiology methods, some of which we have developed, will be exploited including early stage infection inhibition due to specific ultraviolet light wavelengths, DNA repair from trans-lesion synthesis, protein damage assessment using electrophoresis and mass spectrometry techniques, and DNA damage using a new long range PCR technique we recently published. These fundamental findings will be used to develop a tailored wavelength ultraviolet-LED based energy efficient irradiation system to optimize disinfection at lower cost than conventional ultraviolet sources. The work proposed herein will: (1) evaluate inactivation kinetics and wavelength sensitivity of two double stranded DNA viruses,  (2) extend the adenovirus studies to adenoviruses isolated from the environment, (3) evaluate the fundamental role of DNA repair in the cell culture infectivity outcomes,  (4) incorporate newly developed molecular biology-based assays to assess DNA damage and protein damage from ultraviolet light irradiation at varying wavelengths, and,  (5) understand the implications for disinfection using tailored wavelength approaches made possible by the development of nanometer-specific ultraviolet light emitting diodes (LEDs). Regulators and public health officials need information to help make sound decisions for the public sector. The issue of virus disinfection for small systems is currently contentious as the Groundwater Rule specifically forbids the use of UV for any virus inactivation credit due to the high doses required for adenovirus inactivation that cannot currently be field-validated in UV reactors. Therefore, the timing of this research is critical if UV disinfection is going to play any role for virus disinfection in groundwater. Thus, small-systems wanting to use UV for protection of public health, may needlessly suffer.

por.por_cntn:
Adenovirus is a human pathogen commonly found in the environment, including water, and can be spread from human to human mainly using a fecal- oral route of transmission. In this way, the virus is released in the feces, contaminating the environment and infecting new hosts by means of contact with or consumption of contaminated material. Adenovirus have proven to be a challenge to water disinfection because of the extreme resistance to inactivation by UV irradiation (a common and effective technology for water disinfection).

Intellectual merit

This project filled the gap in the inactivation of adenoviruses by UV irradiation related to the inactivation rates between laboratory and environmental strains of adenovirus. Our results demonstrated that adenoviruses found in the environment are more resistant to UV inactivation than laboratory adenoviruses strains.  Adenovirus stocks that are kept and grown in laboratories are commonly used for UV bench experiments and for determination of UV irradiation effectiveness of water disinfection. In addition, the most commonly used adenovirus strains are from the respiratory group (Group C) which are found to be less resistant to UV inactivation than the adenovirus belonging to the enteric group (Adenovirus group F). Enteric adenovirus is the most common adenovirus group found in contaminated waters.

Another knowledge gap is the understanding of how the viral DNA can be repaired by the host cells during the infection. Specifically, adenovirus have proteins where their function is specifically to suppress the DNA damage response and host defenses and to promote the viral infection. Our results showed that adenovirus damaged DNA can be repaired in the very early stages of the infection, before the adenovirus early genes are expressed. This timing allows the damaged DNA to be repaired by the host DNA repair mechanisms, even before the virus can control the host cell to create the cellular conditions that are favorable to its replication.

Experiments were performed to elucidate the effect of different UV wavelengths on damaging different components of the adenovirus virion (infectious viral particle) and our results show that wavelengths lower than 240 nm are very effective in damaging viral proteins and affecting the integrity of the viral particles. UV wavelengths less than 240 nm will enhance the inactivation of adenovirus, which has an ability to repair its genome damage and is subsequently highly resistant to LP UV (254 nm only) irradiation. The development of UV lamps emitting UV wavelengths lower than 240 nm with high electrical efficiency will have a great impact on UV disinfection of viruses. The factors that we need to consider for tailoring of the UV wavelengths are target microbes, inactivation efficacy across wavelengths, and electrical efficiency.

Broader impacts

This project funded an innovative collaboration on UV water disinfection technologies (Dr. Linden) and molecular environmental virology (Dr. Rodríguez) to advance and improve the quality of potable water.  This project enhanced the cross-understanding and collaborations between Public Health Professionals and Engineers.  This NSF project supported an MPH student to learn about engineering principles of water treatment technology and provided support for his thesis research project.  In addition, this project provided funding for an environmental engineering post-doctoral researcher to work in conjunction with Dr. Rodriguez (lead PI), and Dr. Linden (Co PI) on experiments involving molecular biology techniques for the understanding of UV disinfection mechanisms of adenovirus inactivation.  The results of the project were presented in scientific conferences including the International Ultraviolet Light Association World Congress, UNC Water Microbiology Conference and the International Water Association Health-Related Water Microbiology Conference.

The information generated in this project could allow for the development of better UV disinfection technologies by incorporating dual (hi/low) wavelength UV systems for the enhancement of inactivation of DNA-based human viruses such as adenovirus.
